utterances: The Civil Air Patrol has covered the worst-hit areas in Colorado, though pilots will likely be asked to do some more flying today.
This is ALL THINGS CONSIDERED from NPR News.
I'm Robert Siegel.
And I'm Melissa Block.
(Soundbite of protesting)
Thousands of supporters of Sudanese President Omar al-Bashir poured into the streets of Khartoum today.
They shouted their defiance of the arrest warrant issued yesterday by the International Criminal Court accusing President Bashir of war crimes for atrocities in Darfur.
(Foreign language spoken)
Today, Sudan represents the loud voice against all sorts of hegemony and colonialism, Bashir told the crowd.
And he added, we are at war.
Sudan responded to the arrest warrant by expelling at least 13 humanitarian groups from the country, among them Oxfam, Doctors Without Borders and Save the Children.
Those groups have been a lifeline for millions of Sudanese in Darfur and elsewhere.
Reporter Rob Crilly is in Darfur in the city of al-Fashir.
And Rob, you've been talking to some of these aid groups, what are they telling you about what's happened to them?

The aid agencies I've been speaking to say they are really in dire straits, and they spent the morning rushing around trying to sort out as much as they could of their programs, trying to hand them on to local staff or find U.N.
agencies to take over their programs.
But the result was that most of their programs were just simply locked up for the day.
I traveled around some of the aid camps around al-Fashir and I saw clinics closed, schools closed, hospitals padlocked.
I mean, these are the basic services that all the displaced people need.
And the result was that they were simply abandoned today, as international aid workers were forced to leave Darfur.
The U.N.
has said that some of the aid workers also have been detained by security forces, security forces that they said were very intimidating and very aggressive.
Have you heard those reports as well?
Yes.
I think it's been a very unpleasant day for all the international staff as they tried to leave.
I heard about one particular instance involving a French NGO in Nyala, the capitol of South Darfur.
They were detained at gunpoint by national security officers.
Also, all the NGO offices and compounds were visited by government officials.
They began taking down an inventory of all their assets because the government will now be seizing all the equipment used by NGOs.
And this morning, I understand that laptops and desktop computers, satellite phones and mobile phones were all confiscated, making communications very difficult.
I wondered how much you felt that that added to the character.
And how difficult was it for you to bring that?
I don't know if he would have said that when he was still catching passes for the Pittsburgh Steelers.
I suspect probably not.
One more point on this before we get into topic number two, and that is female athletes.
We don't hear a great deal from them.
There was the time when Martina Navratilova, Billie Jean King, for example, were very outspoken and politically active.
We don't see that so much now, although Diana Taurasi from the Phoenix Mercury is mentioned as someone who was involved in supporting Obama this time.
What do you think it is about that issue as far as women athletes getting involved, particularly the black ones, Greg?
Well, I think that, you know, the time when Martina and Billy Jean King were at the forefront, that was a time when women's sports was, you know, at its forefront.
Today women's sports unfortunately has not, you know, does not make the headlines that it did.
It just doesn't command the attention that, you know, that Billie Jean King and Martina Navratilova had in their time.

So, while there are a lot of women athletes who would like to be part of that process, their voice is not being heard for the simple fact that they're not seen on a regular basis on, you know, in newspapers, on ESPN, and all those television broadcasts.
Well, you know there is one woman, two women, black, Serena, Venus, they get an awful lot of ink and air time.
And Venus is - Serena, I'm sorry, coming off a big U.S.
Open win.
They talk a lot about things, but they don't talk about politics do they, D-Will?
No, not at all.
And back another thing in Billy Jean King's time and Martina's era, Title 9, the fight for equal rights with female athletes on the collegiate level was a huge issue here in America.
Also, women's rights was part and parcel of the game, too.

And we don't have that anymore as major issues for female athletes, and so that's another reason in addition to all the things Greg said that are reasons why we don't hear from female athletes as much.
The Williams sisters don't say a whole lot.
They don't say a whole lot even when it come to race and sports, and race in themselves.
They try to be politically correct, if you will, so as not to agitate other players in the locker room, mainly.
Let's move on beyond politics, but let's continue to talk about the Williams sisters, particularly Serena, Greg.
I guess she does all of her talking with her racket, and I guess that's what really counts, doesn't it?
Yeah.
You know, Serena winning another U.S.
Open.
She was very eager, and she was anxious to win another major.

She hasn't won one in a while, and this - you can tell, you know, after the loss to her sister in Wimbledon earlier this summer that she really, really, wanted to get back on that stage, and actually, you know, win another title now.
Not only she wins the U.S.
Open, now she's back as the number one player in the world.
And you can see that, you know, she appreciates more of the game.
You know, she's getting older.
Right now she's turning 27, her sister's 28.
So, as you get older you get more of an appreciation for the things that you accomplish, and you see it in her play right now.
Absolutely.
Nine grand slams for her, and they're still riding the record books.
All right, gentlemen, let's move on to another topic.
Football, football, football, it's here and there's a lot going on, particularly with the quarterbacks.

Let me go to you, Greg, just because New England came into the season as a possible favorite to win it all, and then star quarterback Tom Brady goes down, he's out, and here you have a guy in Matt Cassel coming up as quarterback who has never started a game in college, or in the pros.
Is that right?
That's correct.
The last time he started a game was in the playoffs in his high school in 1999.
So, that's the last time he actually started a game at quarterback.
So, people up there, are they scared?
Well, you know, they were scared initially when they saw number 12 go down last week, and now he's out for the rest of the year.
But the people up here, they believe in Bill Belichick, and does the players.

So, if Bill Belichick thinks that you're good enough to lead a team, the team should have confidence in him, and the fans should have confidence in Matt Cassel if Bill Belichick deems you worthy to start as his quarterback.
We'll find out pretty soon, won't we?
Talk about Brett Favre for a minute, if you will, D-Will.
A lot of eyes looking at him.
They did OK in week one with a victory, and yet they're still the Jets, aren't they?
Yeah, absolutely.
Brett Favre does bring an element of legitimacy to the Jets.
At the same time, I don't know if they have the all-around talent to upstage the Patriots, for instance.

And speaking of Brett, I think Aaron Rodgers performed better than Brett Favre did in week one because he had a lot more pressure on him up in Green Bay replacing Brett Favre than Brett did leading the Jets to a victory over the woeful Miami Dolphins.
Miami Dolphins.
That doesn't even count.
Let's talk about some other quarterback who's having problems that are just - it sounds tragic, and you know who I'm talking about, don't you?
Yes.
Vince Young.
Vince Young, Tennessee Titans.
What's going on with him?
Just to bring the audience up to date, apparently there was a problem with him last week.
He went out of the game, didn't want to go back in.
Coach Jeff Fisher forced him to go back in, he went in, he was hurt.
Now he's out for a couple of weeks, and then this bizarre incident about whether they've had to put the police out.
The family called the team, the team called the police.
They had a big meeting, and now they're saying - his mother's saying she doesn't even know if he still wants to play.
What's going on, Greg?
Hey, I remember at the end of his rookie year he was entertaining thoughts of retiring after his rookie year.
Well, perhaps...
That's right.
Perhaps Vince doesn't have the full heart to play football, or you know, he wore - he's been accustomed to people.

You remember at Texas he was a great player, everyone loved him in Texas in Austin, but this is the National Football League, and if you don't produce - if you don't produce the way the fans think you should produce, they will let you have it.

Instead of in college where they coddle you, and baby you, and it just - I think Vince is not accustomed to criticism, and he - and bottom line, he just has to grow up, and he has to come to grips with that.
Well, D-Will, it seems like there must be more because after all the guy did take the Tennessee Titans to the playoffs just last year.
Yes, as a matter of fact that's true.
I do believe, as Greg said, Vince does have some maturing to do.
At the same time, I also think that this might be a little blown out of proportion in that he was found playing - or watching football at his friend's house, after all.
I think people overreacted.
I think the press is making a bit bigger thing out of this than it is.

Even the statements of Jeff Fishers as recently as yesterday were overblown by the press because Fisher said hey, look, you know, the guys got to get healthy, and he has some issues to take care of and get together.
That's been blown out of proportion into oh my goodness, he's not going to play until he earns his spot back, and stuff like that.
So, some of it is hyperbole, some of it's a maturation process.

Well, the flipside of that, if you go down into Atlanta, their new quarterback, who was a very high draft pick, Ryan, they did pretty well, and people have thoughts now that the Atlanta Falcons may be on the rebound, Greg?
Let's remember that Matt Ryan, you know, actually a rookie quarterback out of Boston College, they played against the Detroit Lions.
And when you have a running back - a team that runs for 300 yards in a game, it makes any quarterback look good.
So, that - but the Atlanta Falcons, you know, they'll be an interesting team to watch, but they're still a rebuilding team.
But we have to take in context who they were playing in the first week, the woeful Detroit Lions.
Well, everything you say is true.
So, let's come across the country now to Oakland, California, D-Will, where another first round - first pick, LaMarcus Russell from LSU was playing with the Oakland Raiders for his first start.
Man, what a long day he had.
Well, it was a long day.
I think he had a few dropped passes.
Important passes were dropped.
Curry dropped a few passes on him.
The Denver Broncos play the Oakland Raiders well because of Mike Shanahan's want to defeat them having coached in Oakland.
LaMarcus Russell's going to face some difficulties this year because he hasn't seen a lot of defenses at full speed, especially in the tough AFC West.
But I think he didn't look as badly as people thought he did, and I think he has a really fine future, personally.
All right, we'll have to wait and find out about that.
One thing before I let you guys go, we've got about a minute or so.
The very, very big game in college football on Saturday between the number one ranked USC Trojans and the number two ranked Ohio State Buckeyes.
It's interesting to have the one and two teams face each other so early in the season, isn't it, Greg?
True.
Yeah.
It's very rare.
And actually, with Ohio State it's going to be very interesting to see how they respond.
Over the last two years they played, you know, they played LSU in the National Championship game last year and got trounced.
Two years ago they lost to Florida in the National Championship game.
So, they have a reputation of losing the big game against real powerful programs.
So, it's going to be not only a statement for Ohio State to see what their made of, but an entire Big Ten Conference and what they are made of.
Final thing is this, give me an answer in about 10 seconds or less, D-Will.
Pack 10, Big 10, SCC, the Big East, ACC, which conference is the strongest?
I think it's very close between the SCC and the Pack 10.
Top to bottom, those two conferences are the best in the country, hands down.
Guys, you're the best.
I'll talk to you in a couple of weeks.
OK, man.
You take care.
Hey, thank you, Tony.
Good to see you Greg, good to hear from you.
You, too.
